elements.content: In this study, we first demonstrated the effect of two types of metal–organic framework–polymer (MOF–polymer) monoliths on in-tube solid-phase microextraction (IT-SPME) of sulfonamides. Sulfonamides were successfully adsorbed onto MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer but were difficult to elute due to these sulfonamides could interact via Lewis acid–base interaction with the presence of Cr­(III) coordinatively unsaturated metal sites (CUS). Moreover, the cage-type topology of MIL-101­(Cr) that could produce multiple pathways thus complicates the desorption of the test analytes from the sorbent. Contrastingly, MIL-53­(Al)–polymer provided weaker Al­(III) CUS, and its one-dimensional channel pore structure could provide an unhindered pathway for sulfonamides transfer during elution. After optimizing the IT-SPME condition such as MOF content, pH of sample matrix, column length, extraction flow rate, and elution volume, the calculated extraction recovery of sulfonamides in MIL-53­(Al)–polymer as analyzed by microemulsion electrokinetic chromatography (MEEKC) were in the range of 40%–90% with relative standard deviations (RSDs) below 5% and a reusability of at least 30 times.
elements.clean_text:
In
this study, we first demonstrated the effect of two types of
metal–organic framework–polymer (MOF–polymer)
monoliths on in-tube solid-phase microextraction (IT-SPME) of sulfonamides.
Sulfonamides were successfully adsorbed onto MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer
but were difficult to elute due to these sulfonamides could interact
via Lewis acid–base interaction with the presence of Cr­(III)
coordinatively unsaturated metal sites (CUS). Moreover, the cage-type
topology of MIL-101­(Cr) that could produce multiple pathways thus
complicates the desorption of the test analytes from the sorbent.
Contrastingly, MIL-53­(Al)–polymer provided weaker Al­(III) CUS,
and its one-dimensional channel pore structure could provide an unhindered
pathway for sulfonamides transfer during elution. After optimizing
the IT-SPME condition such as MOF content, pH of sample matrix, column
length, extraction flow rate, and elution volume, the calculated extraction
recovery of sulfonamides in MIL-53­(Al)–polymer as analyzed
by microemulsion electrokinetic chromatography (MEEKC) were in the
range of 40%–90% with relative standard deviations (RSDs) below
5% and a reusability of at least 30 times.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), built up with clusters of metal ions and organic ligands, have been regarded as the alternative porous materials in diverse fields due to their unique characteristics such as highly ordered structure, large pore volume, and high surface area. Nevertheless, because of the high metal content of MOFs, some solvent molecules could be coordinated partly on the metal atoms to hinder the interaction of the substrate and the MOF, hence, their application would be limited. Coordinatively unsaturated (open) metal site (CUS) is one of the most unique properties of MOFs that can be created through removing the solvent molecule bonded on metal to allow the formation of Lewis acid sites on the pore surface. In this regard, MOFs can make fine candidates for enhancement in gas separations, catalysis, chromatography, matrices, and so on. However, some MOFs have thermal or chemical stability issues that limited their application in specific areas. In order to fully utilize MOFs’ potential, several approaches were being worked out to overcome these issues such as postfunctionalization, metal or ligand exchange, and MOF composites. MOF composites that are hybrid materials combining both the advantages of MOFs and specific materials (enzymes, metal nanoparticles, polymers, quantum dots, nanoporous carbons, etc.), and the established infinite variety of MOFs could be easily engineered with functional materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs), built up with clusters
of metal ions and organic ligands, have been regarded as the alternative
porous materials in diverse fields due to their unique characteristics
such as highly ordered structure, large pore volume, and high surface
area. Nevertheless, because of the high metal content of
MOFs, some solvent molecules could be coordinated partly on the metal
atoms to hinder the interaction of the substrate and the MOF, hence,
their application would be limited. Coordinatively
unsaturated (open) metal site (CUS) is one of the most unique properties
of MOFs that can be created through removing the solvent molecule
bonded on metal to allow the formation of Lewis acid sites on the
pore surface. In this regard, MOFs can make fine candidates for enhancement
in gas separations, catalysis, chromatography, matrices, and so on. However,
some MOFs have thermal or chemical stability issues that limited their
application in specific areas. In order to fully utilize MOFs’
potential, several approaches were being worked out to overcome these
issues such as postfunctionalization, metal or ligand exchange, and MOF composites. MOF composites that are hybrid
materials combining both the advantages of MOFs and specific materials
(enzymes, metal nanoparticles, polymers, quantum dots, nanoporous
carbons, etc.), and the established infinite variety of MOFs could
be easily engineered with functional materials.

elements.content: Sulfonamides were first developed as antimicrobial agents named Prontosil in the 1930s by the Bayer company and is structurally connected to amino and sulfonyl groups. In recent years, more than 10 sulfonamides and their derivatives are used in food-producing animals for therapeutic, prophylactic, and growth-promoting purposes, e.g., sulfamethoxazole and sulfadimidine. However, the use of sulfonamides in intensive animal production poses risk due to high amounts of residue transfer to the environment through animal wastes. Moreover, use of these antibiotics on animals could be a threat to human health since it is a known fact that animal bacteria can develop drug resistance even in subtherapeutic levels. Hence, several worldwide organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO) or Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) set safe maximum residue limits (MRLs) of 100 ng g–1 of sulfonamide drugs in food of animal origin. In this context, it is crucial to develop matrix cleaning techniques to be able to carry out unbiased detection of target analytes in complicated matrices such as food.

Sulfonamides were first developed as antimicrobial
agents named
Prontosil in the 1930s by the Bayer company and is structurally connected
to amino and sulfonyl groups. In recent
years, more than 10 sulfonamides and their derivatives are used in
food-producing animals for therapeutic, prophylactic, and growth-promoting
purposes, e.g., sulfamethoxazole and sulfadimidine. However, the use of sulfonamides in intensive animal production
poses risk due to high amounts of residue transfer to the environment
through animal wastes. Moreover, use of these antibiotics on animals
could be a threat to human health since it is a known fact that animal
bacteria can develop drug resistance even in subtherapeutic levels. Hence, several worldwide organizations such
as the World Health Organization (WHO) or Food and Agriculture Organization
of the United Nations (FAO) set safe maximum residue limits (MRLs)
of 100 ng g–1 of sulfonamide drugs in food of animal
origin. In this context, it is crucial
to develop matrix cleaning techniques to be able to carry out unbiased
detection of target analytes in complicated matrices such as food.

elements.content: Solid-phase microextraction (SPME) is a matrix cleaning technique used in complicated sample treatment. With the advantage of less solvent and solid sorbent consumed in the process, wherein the use of small amounts of the solid sorbent or liquid polymer in appropriate format are exposed to the sample for extraction process, this technique combines sampling, analyte isolation, and enrichment into a single step. Among those SPME techniques, in-tube SPME (IT-SPME), which utilized porous monolithic materials as sorbent with several advantages such as high flexibility, easy functionalization, rapid mass transfer and high permeability under continuous flow, has received great attention on environmental, biological, and pharmaceutical analysis. Wen et al. demonstrated polymer monolith coupled to high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) for sulfonamide detection in 28 min. Zheng et al. used poly­(methacrylic acid-ethylene dimethacrylate) (MAA-EDMA) column for 14 kinds of sulfonamides extraction in milk sample, and detected by online HPLC-MS mode. The recovery range was 80.4–119.8%, and the relative standard deviations (RSDs) were below 10.5%. However, swelling and cracking occurred during the preparation of polymer and silica materials that resulted in the limitations of extraction.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-phase microextraction (SPME) is a matrix cleaning technique
used in complicated sample treatment. With the advantage of less solvent
and solid sorbent consumed in the process, wherein the use of small
amounts of the solid sorbent or liquid polymer in appropriate format
are exposed to the sample for extraction process, this technique combines
sampling, analyte isolation, and enrichment into a single step. Among those SPME techniques, in-tube SPME (IT-SPME), which utilized
porous monolithic materials as sorbent with several advantages such
as high flexibility, easy functionalization, rapid mass transfer and
high permeability under continuous flow, has received great attention
on environmental, biological, and pharmaceutical analysis. Wen et al. demonstrated polymer monolith coupled to high-performance
liquid chromatography (HPLC) for sulfonamide detection in 28 min. Zheng et al. used poly­(methacrylic acid-ethylene
dimethacrylate) (MAA-EDMA) column for 14 kinds of sulfonamides extraction
in milk sample, and detected by online HPLC-MS mode. The recovery
range was 80.4–119.8%, and the relative standard deviations
(RSDs) were below 10.5%. However, swelling
and cracking occurred during the preparation of polymer and silica
materials that resulted in the limitations of extraction.

elements.content: Recently, the use of MOFs as adsorbent material for SPME was also developed. Yan and co-workers first used MOF-199 fiber as sorbent for benzene homologues polycyclic aromatic carbons extraction, which showed a relative recovery of between 87 and 106%, and the RSDs of fiber-to-fiber was below 3.5–9.4%. Yu et al. demonstrated zeolitic imidazolate framework-90 (ZIF-90) to functionalize silica fibers for SPME of phenolic endocrine disruptors in environmental samples. The results indicated high relative recovery (90%–104%), high reproducibility (<6.7%), and high reusability (170 recycle). In our previous report, we demonstrated the potential of metal–organic framework–organic polymer (MOF–polymer) as SPME adsorbent. Lin et al. first prepared MIL-101­(Cr)-poly­(butyl methacrylate-co-ethylene dimethacrylate) (MIL-101-poly­(BMA-EDMA)) columns with high permeability for penicillin extraction. This fast fabrication of MOF–polymer column not only overcame high back pressure that derived from MOF packed column but also gave as one of the best recoveries (63–96.2%) for penicillin extraction efficiency. Furthermore, the reproducibility of column-to-column was below 6.2%, and the reusability was up to 45 times.

45 times.

elements.content: Herein, we postulated that sulfonamides could be easily anchored onto CUS on the MOF surface because its amine group could act as a Lewis base. To emphasize the effect of CUS of the well-known MOFs with the same valence (M3+) but different groups, namely, MIL-101­(Cr) and MIL-53­(Al) with different strength of Lewis acid and topologies (cage- or channel-type pores) of MOFs, we explored the channel-type MIL53­(Al)-poly­(BMA-EDMA) and cage-type MIL-101­(Cr)-poly­(BMA-EDMA) columns for IT-SPME of 9 sulfonamide antibiotics (sulfaquinoaline (SQL), sulfadimethoxine (SDM), sulfisoxazole (SIZ), sulfapyridine (SPD), sulfamethazine (SMZ), sulfamerazine (SMR), sulfadiazine (SDZ), sulfamonomethoxine (SMX), and sulfathiazole (STZ)). To optimize the extraction efficiency of sulfonamides, the following issues were evaluated: MOF content, pH of sample matrix, column length, extraction flow rate, and elution volume, while a microemulsion electrokinetic chromatography (MEEKC) was used to analyze the extracted sulfonamides.

and elution volume, while a microemulsion electrokinetic chromatography

elements.content: All chemicals and reagents used were at least of analytical grade. Sulfaquinoxaline (SQL, pK a1 = 1.77, pK a2 = 5.65), sulfadimethoxine (SDM, pK a1 = 1.30, pK a 2 = 6.21), sulfisoxazole (SIZ, pK a1 = 1.52, pK a2 = 4.83), sulfapyridine (SPD, pK a1 = 2.9, pK a2 = 8.54), sulfamethazine (SMZ, pK a1 = 1.95, pK a2 = 7.45), sulfamerazine (SMR, pK a1 = 1.64, pK a2 = 6.98), and sulfadiazine (SDZ, pK a1 = 1.64, pK a2 = 6.50) were purchased from Sigma (Steinheim, Germany). Sulfamonomethoxine (SMX, pK a1 = 1.42, pK a2 = 6.67) and sulfathiazole (STZ, pK a1 = 2.31, pK a2 = 7.24) were obtained from MP Biomedicals (Eschwege, Germany). The above nine sulfonamides were used as test analytes in this study. Standard stock solutions were prepared at 500 μg mL–1 in acetonitrile (ACN). Before IT-SPME, sulfonamides were diluted to 75 μg mL–1 by ACN, and then diluted to 3 μg mL–1 with phosphate buffered saline (PBS, pH 2–8). Ethylene dimethacrylate (EDMA) (98%) (ACROS, NJ, USA) and butyl methacrylate (BMA) (95%) (Ward Hill, MA, USA), and azobis­(isobutyronitrile) (AIBN) (Showa, Tokyo, Japan) were used for polymer preparation, while 3-trimethoxysilylpropyl methacrylate (MSMA, 98%) was purchased from ACROS (Geel, Belgium) for column vinylization. A 0.8 × 100 mm capillary tube was used for MOF–polymer fabrication.

elements.content: The capillary electrophoresis (CE) experiment was performed with a Hewlett-Packard3D CE system equipped with a 3-D UV–vis detector (Waldbronn, Germany). All sulfonamides were analyzed in a 48.5 cm total length of (40 cm to detector) 50 μm I.D. and 375 μm O.D. (Polymicro Technologies Inc.) uncoated capillary column. A Shimadzu instrument model LC-10AT (Kyoto, Japan) was used for washing and equilibrating the MOF–polymer columns. A KD Scientific syringe pump (Holliston, MA, USA) was equipped for extraction experiment. A scanning electron microscope (SEM) model JSM-7600F (JEOL, Japan) was used for the polymeric morphology observation. A surface area analysis equipment model Micromeretics Tristar 3000 (Norcross, GA, USA) was employed for surface area measurement. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was used for the examination of the MOF–polymer pattern.

Apparatus

uncoated capillary column. A Shimadzu instrument model LC-10AT (Kyoto,

A surface area analysis equipment model Micromeretics Tristar 3000

pattern.

elements.content: MIL-53­(Al), Al­(OH)­[O2C–C6H4–CO2], was synthesized and activated according to the literature. Briefly, MIL-53­(Al) was hydrothermally synthesized under microwave-assisted reaction by a mixture of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O (375 mg, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-BDC, C6H4-1,4-(CO2H)2, 83 mg, 0.5 mmol) and H2O (6 mL) in a 100 mL Teflon autoclave placed in a microwave oven. The mixture was heated at 220 °C for 30 min. The resulting white powder sample was collected by filtration, washed with purified water, and dried at room temperature. The MIL-53­(Al) was vacuumed and heated at 150 °C for 1 day before further experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of MIL-53­(Al)
MIL-53­(Al), Al­(OH)­[O2C–C6H4–CO2],
was synthesized and activated according to the literature. Briefly, MIL-53­(Al) was hydrothermally synthesized
under microwave-assisted reaction by a mixture of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O (375 mg, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic
acid (1,4-BDC, C6H4-1,4-(CO2H)2, 83 mg, 0.5 mmol) and H2O (6 mL) in a 100 mL Teflon
autoclave placed in a microwave oven. The mixture was heated at 220
°C for 30 min. The resulting white powder sample was collected
by filtration, washed with purified water, and dried at room temperature.
The MIL-53­(Al) was vacuumed and heated at 150 °C for 1 day before
further experiments.

elements.content: MIL-101­(Cr), Cr3F­(H2O)2O­[O2C–C6H4–CO2]3·25H2O, was synthesized and activated according to the literature. Briefly, MIL-101­(Cr) was hydrothermally synthesized by a mixture of Cr­(NO3)3·9H2O (800 mg, 2.0 mmol), 1,4-BDC (332 mg, 2 mmol), and hydrofluoric acid (HF) (0.1 mL, 0.5 mmol), which were dissolved in 9.6 mL of H2O in a 100 mL Teflon autoclave. The mixture was heated at 220 °C for 8 h. The as-synthesized green powder was collected by filtration, and washed with dimethylformamide (DMF) and ethanol three times. The MIL-101­(Cr) was vacuumed and heated at 150 °C overnight before further experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of MIL-101­(Cr)
MIL-101­(Cr),
Cr3F­(H2O)2O­[O2C–C6H4–CO2]3·25H2O, was synthesized and activated according to the literature. Briefly, MIL-101­(Cr) was hydrothermally synthesized
by a mixture of Cr­(NO3)3·9H2O (800 mg, 2.0 mmol), 1,4-BDC (332 mg, 2 mmol), and hydrofluoric
acid (HF) (0.1 mL, 0.5 mmol), which were dissolved in 9.6 mL of H2O in a 100 mL Teflon autoclave. The mixture was heated at
220 °C for 8 h. The as-synthesized green powder was collected
by filtration, and washed with dimethylformamide (DMF) and ethanol
three times. The MIL-101­(Cr) was vacuumed and heated at 150 °C
overnight before further experiments.

elements.content: Prior to the preparation of a MOF–polymer column, the inner wall of a 0.8 × 100 mm capillary tube was vinylized to anchor polymer, as described in our previous article. Briefly, 0.1 M NaOH, deionized H2O, and methanol was used to flush the capillary tube at flow rates (mL min–1) of 0.5, 2, and 2 for 20, 20, and 5 min, respectively, and was followed by N2(g) purge for another 30 min. After drying, a MSMA/MeOH (1:1, v/v) solution was used to fill the capillary tube, and then both ends were sealed with rubber and the tube was immersed in a 37 °C water bath for 17 h. Afterward, the column was washed with MeOH (2 mL for 13 min), H2O (2 mL for 13 min), and dried with N2(g). For the preparation of the MOF–polymer column, different amounts of MOF were suspended in a solution composed of monomers (BMA (3.6 μL) and EDMA (5.4 μL), porogenic solvents (water (3 μL), ionic liquid, [C6mim]­[BF4] (38 μL)), and initiator (AIBN (0.5 mg)). The mixed solution was sonicated for 15 min until it became homogeneous, then it was used to fill the vinylized capillary by syringe injection. After both ends of the capillary were sealed with rubber and immersed in water, in situ polymerization under microwave irradiation (900 W, 5 min) followed. The MOF–polymer column was then washed with methanol by an LC pump, while the MOF–polymer formed in the vial was Soxhlet extracted with methanol for 24 h, vacuum-dried overnight, and was used for surface area, PXRD pattern, and SEM characterization.

Preparation of MOF–Polymer
Column
Prior to the
preparation of a MOF–polymer column, the inner wall of a 0.8
× 100 mm capillary tube was vinylized to anchor polymer, as described
in our previous article. Briefly, 0.1 M NaOH,
deionized H2O, and methanol was used to flush the capillary
tube at flow rates (mL min–1) of 0.5, 2, and 2 for
20, 20, and 5 min, respectively, and was followed by N2(g) purge for another 30 min. After drying, a MSMA/MeOH (1:1, v/v) solution
was used to fill the capillary tube, and then both ends were sealed
with rubber and the tube was immersed in a 37 °C water bath for
17 h. Afterward, the column was washed with MeOH (2 mL for 13 min),
H2O (2 mL for 13 min), and dried with N2(g).
For the preparation of the
MOF–polymer column, different amounts of MOF were suspended
in a solution composed of monomers (BMA (3.6 μL) and EDMA (5.4
μL), porogenic solvents (water (3 μL), ionic liquid, [C6mim]­[BF4] (38 μL)), and initiator (AIBN (0.5
mg)). The mixed solution was sonicated for 15 min until it became
homogeneous, then it was used to fill the vinylized capillary by syringe
injection. After both ends of the capillary were sealed with rubber
and immersed in water, in situ polymerization under microwave irradiation
(900 W, 5 min) followed. The MOF–polymer column was then washed
with methanol by an LC pump, while the MOF–polymer formed in
the vial was Soxhlet extracted with methanol for 24 h, vacuum-dried
overnight, and was used for surface area, PXRD pattern, and SEM characterization.

elements.content: The IT-SPME device is composed of an extraction column and a syringe pump connected through a connector and a peek fitting (Scheme S1). Prior to the extraction of sulfonamide analytes, the column was preconditioned by using MeOH (0.5 mL) and phosphate buffered saline (PBS; 0.5 mL) at different pH values (2–8) with a flow rate of 0.1 mL min–1. Sulfonamide solution (2 mL, 3 μg mL–1) in PBS buffer (pH 2–8) was loaded into the preconditioned syringe, washed with PBS buffer (pH 2) at 0.1 mL min–1 and eluted with MeOH (1 mL, 0.1 mL min–1) (Scheme S2).
elements.clean_text:
Fabrication, Operational Conditions, and Extraction Procedure
of MOF–Polymer for IT-SPME
The IT-SPME device is composed
of an extraction column and a syringe pump connected through a connector
and a peek fitting (Scheme S1). Prior to
the extraction of sulfonamide analytes, the column was preconditioned
by using MeOH (0.5 mL) and phosphate buffered saline (PBS; 0.5 mL)
at different pH values (2–8) with a flow rate of 0.1 mL min–1. Sulfonamide solution (2 mL, 3 μg mL–1) in PBS buffer (pH 2–8) was loaded into the preconditioned
syringe, washed with PBS buffer (pH 2) at 0.1 mL min–1 and eluted with MeOH (1 mL, 0.1 mL min–1) (Scheme S2).

elements.content: The MEEKC method used for sulfonamides separation followed our previous literature with slight modifications. The microemulsion solution was prepared on a w/v basis (g mL–1) in 50 mM phosphate solution (pH 2.0). After the mixing of surfactant (SDS, 3.31%), cosurfactant (1-propanol, 6.61%), and oil (cyclohexane, 0.81%) to phosphate solutions of pH 2.0 (50 mM, 89.27%), the mixture was then sonicated for 30 min until homogeneous. The fused silica capillary was conditioned prior to separation by washing with 0.1 M NaOH (3 min), deionized water (4 min), 0.1 M HCl (5 min) and then with buffer (5 min). Sulfonamide standard solutions (30 μg mL–1) were pressure-injected into the capillary column for MEEKC (50 mbar, 3 s). Sulfonamide standards were mixed with phosphate buffer (50 mM) of pH 2.0 at a ratio of 1:9 (v:v). Separations were carried out using an electrical voltage of −20 kV. The temperature of the capillary was maintained at 30 °C. The detection wavelength was 200 nm. The extraction recovery (%) (or adsorption efficiency (%)) was calculated by the ratio of eluted sulfonamide (or unloaded sulfonamide) concentration to sulfonamide standard concentration.
elements.clean_text:
Operation Condition for
MEEKC
The MEEKC method used
for sulfonamides separation followed our previous literature with
slight modifications. The microemulsion
solution was prepared on a w/v basis (g mL–1) in
50 mM phosphate solution (pH 2.0). After the mixing of surfactant
(SDS, 3.31%), cosurfactant (1-propanol, 6.61%), and oil (cyclohexane,
0.81%) to phosphate solutions of pH 2.0 (50 mM, 89.27%), the mixture
was then sonicated for 30 min until homogeneous. The fused silica
capillary was conditioned prior to separation by washing with 0.1
M NaOH (3 min), deionized water (4 min), 0.1 M HCl (5 min) and then
with buffer (5 min). Sulfonamide standard solutions (30 μg mL–1) were pressure-injected into the capillary column
for MEEKC (50 mbar, 3 s). Sulfonamide standards were mixed with phosphate
buffer (50 mM) of pH 2.0 at a ratio of 1:9 (v:v). Separations were
carried out using an electrical voltage of −20 kV. The temperature
of the capillary was maintained at 30 °C. The detection wavelength
was 200 nm. The extraction recovery (%) (or adsorption efficiency
(%)) was calculated by the ratio of eluted sulfonamide (or unloaded
sulfonamide) concentration to sulfonamide standard concentration.

elements.content: The HPLC analysis was performed using a Shimadzu HPLC equipped with UV–vis detector (10 mm of light path, 12 μL of flow cell) and a Shim-pack GIST C18 (5 μm) column (4.6 × 250 mm) at 315 K. Sulfonamides were separated in a gradient mode (0–10 min, 12% B; 10–20 min, 12%–20% B; 20–45 min, 20%–25% B; 45–48 min, 25%–80% B; 48–53 min, 80% B; 53–58 min, 80%–12% B, where B was composed of 100% ACN with 0.1% formic acid (FA, v/v) while 100% water with 0.1% FA (v/v) for solvent A. The separation was carried out at a flow rate of 1 mL min–1 and detected at 254 nm. A 3 μL sample was injected via an auto sampler with a 100 μL sample loop.

elements.content: Prior to the characterization of MOF–polymer, a preliminary examination of the synthesized MIL-53­(Al) and MIL-101­(Cr) was conducted. a,b shows the PXRD patterns of MIL-53­(Al) and MIL-101­(Cr), respectively, and are similar to previous literatures demonstrating that our synthesized MOFs are highly crystalline. The calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area was about 2737 m2 g–1 for MIL-101­(Cr) (Figure S2), which is consistent with literatures. However, it was slightly decreased to 411 m2 g–1 for MIL-53­(Al) (Figure S2) when compared to 1140 m2 g–1 reported by Loiseau et al., possibly due to the strong affinity between H2O molecule and Al metal, thereby hindering N2 adsorption on MIL-53­(Al). In order to characterize the incorporation of MOF into poly­(BMA-EDMA), PXRD, SEM, N2 adsorption–desorption, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) were used for determination. Obviously, the PXRD patterns of MIL-53­(Al)–polymer (a) and MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer (b) matched that of the as-synthesized MIL-53­(Al) and MIL-101­(Cr), demonstrating the successful preparation of MOF–polymer, without alterations of the MIL-53­(Al) and MIL-101­(Cr) structures, under microwave-assisted heating.

elements.content: FTIR was employed to characterize the functional groups present in MIL-53­(Al), MIL-101­(Cr), neat polymer, and MOF–polymer. As shown in c and d, the absorption bands at 2800–3000 and 1730 cm–1 were assigned to C–H and CO stretching, respectively and were derived from neat poly­(BMA-EDMA). Aromatic CC bending was observed at 1600 cm–1, which belonged to the 1,4-BDC linker of MIL-53­(Al) and MIL-101­(Cr) (c, d).

elements.content: SEM images illustrated the similarity in the pore shape and structure of neat polymer (Figure S1) and MOF–polymer, revealing that the original morphologies of these materials were well retained after in situ polymerization (a, b). Furthermore, SEM images and N2 isotherms also indicated that large through pores (∼1 μm), micropores (17 Å) and mesopores (23, 26 Å) were coexistent in MOF–polymer that resulted in higher permeability compared to the MOF column. In addition, the elemental mapping results from SEM-energy dispersive spectrometer (SEM-EDS) showed that MOF particles were well-dispersed in the polymer skeletons after in situ polymerization (Figure S3).

elements.content: From the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (c,d), the calculated BET surface area of neat polymer was increased from 2 to 10 and 2 to 232 m2 g–1 for MIL-53­(Al)–polymer and MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer, respectively. Even though the surface area was not high as the pristine MOFs, which can be due to the accumulated polymer onto the MOF surface that hinders the nitrogen gas in going through the MOFs’ pore, the monoliths are still comparable to our previous report on MIL-100­(Cr)–polymer (15.2 m2 g–1), and UiO-66–polymer (16.4 m2 g–1), etc. With the above observations, it can be concluded that both MOF–polymers exhibited high surface area, macro-/microporosity, and organic/metal functionality, which can be a promising sorbent for sulfonamides extraction even if the surface area for MIL-53­(Al)–polymer had only a little increase.

elements.content: Neat poly­(BMA-EDMA) was examined first for sulfonamides extraction. With results shown in Figure S4, most of the sulfonamides were not adsorbed onto poly­(BMA-EDMA) sorbent during the loading process, resulting in a low recovery of between 4%–46%. Apparently, the poly­(BMA-EDMA) polymer was a weak sorbent to extract sulfonamides possibly because the interaction between the methacrylate-based polymer with sulfonamides’ amino and sulfonyl groups may only be dependent on van der Waals interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Neat Poly­(BMA-EDMA) for Sulfonamides Extraction
Neat
poly­(BMA-EDMA) was examined first for sulfonamides extraction. With
results shown in Figure S4, most of the
sulfonamides were not adsorbed onto poly­(BMA-EDMA) sorbent during
the loading process, resulting in a low recovery of between 4%–46%.
Apparently, the poly­(BMA-EDMA) polymer was a weak sorbent to extract
sulfonamides possibly because the interaction between the methacrylate-based
polymer with sulfonamides’ amino and sulfonyl groups may only
be dependent on van der Waals interaction.

elements.content: As mentioned before, MOF–polymer demonstrated a highly crystalline structure, hybrid organic/metal functionality and good permeability. Furthermore, the window pore sizes of MIL-53­(Al) and MIL-101­(Cr) were between 12 and 17 Å, which were either larger or similar to the molecular sizes of sulfonamides (6–20 Å, Table S1), hence the MOFs were suitable sorbents for sulfonamide extraction. In order to compare its extraction efficiency with neat polymer, the composition and ratio of MIL-101­(Cr) and MIL-53­(Al) (2 mg, 25% (w/w), relative to monomer weight) mixed with monomer solution were kept constant. The MOF–monomer mixed solution was loaded into a vinylized capillary tube and heated for 5 min via microwave-assisted heating. The resulting MOF–polymer was then connected to the IT-SPME device for extraction experiments. As shown in , almost 60% of sulfonamide molecules were not retained on MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer after sample loading (a), and only 40% of the sulfonamide molecules, consisting of four sulfonamide compounds (SQL, SDM, SIZ, and SMX), were adsorbed on MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer (the extraction recoveries were around 46%, 41%, 29%, and 14%, respectively) (d, Figure S5). Previous studies have demonstrated high correlation between the extraction efficiency and MOF amount used, therefore the amount of MIL-101­(Cr) in the MIL-101­(Cr)-monomer mixture was increased to 33% and 50% for further investigation. Results generated from this increase in MOF content showed that the amount of sulfonamide residues in the sample solution after sample loading was decreased (b–c), which indicated that the amount of MIL-101­(Cr) greatly influenced the adsorption efficiency of sulfonamide analytes on MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer. However, the same results were obtained as the above experiment, wherein among the sulfonamide analytes loaded, only four analytes were successfully desorbed (SQL, SDM, SIZ, and SMX with extraction recoveries around 56%, 51%, 36% and 20%, respectively) (d) as measured from the eluted solution while the rest of the test analytes (SPD, STZ, SMZ, SMR, and SDZ) were still retained on the MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer, even if the volume of the elution solution was increased to three-folds (Figure S6). To explain this phenomenon, we postulated two reasons that possibly influenced the retention of these analytes onto the MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer and thus hindered their elution. Looking at the structure of these retained analytes, they are all NH2-containing sulfonamides (Table S1) that could strongly attach to the unsaturated chromium sites on MIL-101­(Cr) surface via a Lewis acid–base interaction (Figure S9). Another reason could be related to the cage-type framework of MIL-101­(Cr) constructed by super tetrahedral building unit (ST) corner-sharing with an augmented MTN zeotype architecture, that possibly produced multiple pathways, making it more difficult for sulfonamide molecules to desorb from MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer during the elution step (Scheme S3a,c).

were obtained as the above experiment, wherein among the sulfonamide

elements.content: In order to clarify the effect of CUS and MOF topology on the extraction efficiency, MIL-53­(Al) was used instead of MIL-101­(Cr) as the MOF–polymer sorbent for comparison purposes. Low traces of sulfonamides were detected in the loading solution after sample loading, indicating that the sulfonamides were almost adsorbed on MIL-53­(Al)–polymer (a), similar to the results obtained in MIL-101­(Cr) (with 50% MOF content). In contrast to MIL-101­(Cr) with lower extraction recoveries as observed in d, sulfonamide recoveries increased from 18%–80% with all nine sulfonamides eluted as opposed to only four in MIL-101­(Cr), proving that the incorporation of MIL-53­(Al) (25% content) in MIL-53­(Al)–polymer greatly enhanced the sulfonamides desorption (c). MIL-53­(Al) contains relatively low Lewis acid sites and has a topology built up of unidimensional chains of corner-sharing AlO4(OH)2 octahedral linked by 1,4-BDC ligands, thus the weak Lewis acid–base interaction (Figure S9) as well as the linear lozenge-shaped channels would not hinder the elution of sulfonamides (Scheme S3b). With the extraction efficiency demonstrated by MIL-53­(Al)–polymer sorbent, the succeeding experiments dealt with the optimization of extraction efficiency such as sample matrix pH, length of extraction column, MIL-53­(Al) content, and elution volume.

elements.content: Sample matrix plays an important role in any extraction especially when the protonation or deprotonation of analytes are controlled by pH. In this study, pK a1 and pK a2 of sulfonamides are around 1.3–1.9 and 5.6–8.5, respectively. Herein, different pHs (pH 3–7) of the sample matrix were examined for evaluating extraction performance as shown in . The sulfonamide recoveries were increased at pH 3 to pH 5 and largely decreased with pH above 5. The likely reason for this is the deprotonation of sulfonamides and the linker 1,4-BDC in MIL-53­(Al) at pH 6–9 causing the electrostatic repulsion between analytes and the stationary phase that resulted in a decrease in the adsorption of sulfonamides. Hence, pH 5 was chosen as the optimized sample matrix.

elements.content: Extraction efficiency could be enhanced by increasing the length of the extraction column or increasing the MOF amount. A 3–5 cm length of MIL-53­(Al)–polymer columns were compared for extraction efficiency. As shown in , analyte recoveries were increased by 5–20% when the column length was increased to 4 cm. Moreover, recoveries of analytes 5–9 were increased by 20% in the 5 cm column length, although recoveries of analytes 1–4 were slightly decreased by ∼3%. Since the observed pump back pressure was too high for the 6 cm length column (data not shown), a 5 cm column length was used for further experiments.

elements.content: Based from the results in previous sections, the use of MIL-53­(Al) as coadsorbent significantly influenced sulfonamides extraction efficiency and even better extraction efficiency by providing more stationary phase when the column length was increased. In this section, we tried to vary the amount of MIL-53­(Al) (25%–50% (w/w) relative to monomer weight) and study its effect on extraction efficiency. As what we were expecting, better extraction efficiency was observed with higher MOF content in the extraction column. For instance, the recoveries of SPD, STZ, and SMZ was increased from 27%, 38%, and 28% to 75%, 80%, and 78%, respectively, when 50% MIL-53­(Al) was incorporated into polymer as sorbent (a 35–50% enhancement) (). However, as the MOF content was further increased to 60%, a high pump back pressure was observed (data not shown), prompting the use of 50% MOF as the optimum content in the next experiments.

elements.content: The extraction time was mainly dependent on the flow rate. To decrease the time spent on the extraction processes, we raised the flow rate from 0.1 mL min–1 to 0.15 mL min–1. As shown in Figure S7, there was no difference in the recovery between the flow rates at 0.1 and 0.125 mL min–1, but the total extraction time was reduced from 45 to 36 min. However, the stationary phase was detached from the capillary tube when the extraction flow rate was increased further resulting in poor recovery and low reproducibility, even if the extraction time was shortened to 30 min for the 0.150 mL min–1 flow rate. Considering the extraction time consumed and the extraction efficiency, 0.125 mL min–1 was chosen as the optimized flow rate.

difference in the recovery between the flow rates at 0.1 and 0.125
mL min–1, but the total extraction time was reduced
from 45 to 36 min. However, the stationary phase was detached from
the capillary tube when the extraction flow rate was increased further
resulting in poor recovery and low reproducibility, even if the extraction
time was shortened to 30 min for the 0.150 mL min–1 flow rate. Considering the extraction time consumed and the extraction
efficiency, 0.125 mL min–1 was chosen as the optimized
flow rate.

elements.content: The amount of elution solvent was also investigated by increasing its volume from 0.6 to 1.0 mL to determine the best extraction recovery for sulfonamides. As shown in , the extraction recoveries of sulfonamides were increased from 37%–80% to 41%–89% as well as the extraction reproducibility was enhanced from 15% RSDs to 6% RSDs when the elution volume was increased from 0.6 to 1.0 mL, respectively. The above result indicates that an inadequate desorption of the analytes was observed when low volume of solvent was utilized. Moreover, since the nine sulfonamides have wide range log P values (a partition-coefficient measurement of solute for its hydrophilic or hydrophobic property) (−0.074 to 1.429, Table S1), it is possible that their interactions with MIL-53­(Al)–polymer are also different, thereby resulting to an extraction recovery range of 40%–90%.

elements.content: From the previous section, the optimized condition for sulfonamides extraction were: 50% MIL-53­(Al) content, pH 5 sample matrix, 5 cm column length, 1.0 mL elution volume and 0.125 mL min–1 flow rate. The recovery of sulfonamides for intraday, interday, and column-to-column were 40.6%–92.9%, 40.6%–91.2%, and 41.9%–89.7%, respectively, while the RSDs were 1.8%–4.7%, 0.8–6.4%, and 0.5%–5.3%, respectively (). The high relative linearity of calibration curve in the dynamic range of 0.5–50 μg mL–1 (R 2 = 0.9975–0.9996) and limit of detection (LOD) between 0.36 and 0.85 ppm () demonstrated that the MIL-53­(Al)–polymer adsorbent for sulfonamide antibiotics extraction was highly reproducible and with high extraction efficiency. In order to demonstrate the potential of MIL-53­(Al)–polymer for SPME of trace levels sulfonamides (0.1 ppm) as well as increasing the detection sensitivity, HPLC-UV was utilized for further analysis as described in the experimental section. The results are shown in Figure S10 and Table S2. The obtained LODs of sulfonamides were in the range of 0.039 to 0.1 μg mL–1, which are in accordance with the WHO and FAO regulations for sulfonamide drugs in food from animal origin. Moreover, in contrast to the LODs obtained by CE-MEEKC method (0.36–0.85 μg mL–1), the HPLC-UV can further enhance the detection sensitivity 10-fold. This result was also comparable to or even better than other studies for sulfonamide antibiotic extraction (Table S2). Also, in order to analyze the sulfonamides in environment sample, the water sample taken from fish pond was spiked with 0.1 μg mL–1 of sulfonamides and subsequently applied in SPME prior to HPLC-UV analysis. As shown in Figure S11, our SPME approach can enhance the detection sensitivity for the trace-level sulfonamide drugs, which is in accordance with the regulations of the WHO and FAO. Furthermore, the MIL-53­(Al)–polymer can be reused more than 30 times without any significant decrease in the extraction recovery (Figure S8). More importantly, the MIL-53­(Al)–polymer, after 30 extraction times, still maintained a low backpressure (4 psi), which is similar to the initial condition at flow rate of 0.125 mL min–1, indicating that the MOF–polymer composite is stable and could overcome the shortcomings of neat polymer.

Dynamic range: 0.5, 2.5, 5, 25, 50 μg mL–1.

LOD: S/N = 3 was calculated based on the obtained S/N ratio from the CE-MEEKC method.

In summary, we demonstrated for the first time the effect of MOFs with different CUS and topology on the extraction efficiencies of sulfonamide model compounds carrying the NH2 moiety. Sulfonamides were completely adsorbed on MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer but were difficult to desorb due to the presence of strong Lewis acid–base interaction and possible multiple pathways for elution. In contrast to MIL-101­(Cr), MIL-53­(Al) in MOF–polymer carries lower CUS on surface and its unidimensional channel pore morphology can conduct a faster way for sulfonamides transfer during elution. The rapid IT-SPME technique utilizing a highly stable MIL-53­(Al)–polymer sorbent for nine sulfonamide antibiotics gave recoveries between 40%–90%, with RSDs of below 5%, and can be reused for at least 30 times without significant loss in extraction performance. This novel hybrid MIL-53­(Al)–polymer overcame the drawbacks usually encountered in traditional sorbents such as polymer- or silica-based PMME, for example, swelling and cracking. This study could further provide a variety of applications in the analysis of environmental samples, drugs, pollutants, etc.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In
summary, we demonstrated for the first time the effect of MOFs
with different CUS and topology on the extraction efficiencies of
sulfonamide model compounds carrying the NH2 moiety. Sulfonamides
were completely adsorbed on MIL-101­(Cr)–polymer but were difficult
to desorb due to the presence of strong Lewis acid–base interaction
and possible multiple pathways for elution. In contrast to MIL-101­(Cr),
MIL-53­(Al) in MOF–polymer carries lower CUS on surface and
its unidimensional channel pore morphology can conduct a faster way
for sulfonamides transfer during elution. The rapid IT-SPME technique
utilizing a highly stable MIL-53­(Al)–polymer sorbent for nine
sulfonamide antibiotics gave recoveries between 40%–90%, with
RSDs of below 5%, and can be reused for at least 30 times without
significant loss in extraction performance. This novel hybrid MIL-53­(Al)–polymer
overcame the drawbacks usually encountered in traditional sorbents
such as polymer- or silica-based PMME, for example, swelling and cracking.
This study could further provide a variety of applications in the
analysis of environmental samples, drugs, pollutants, etc.
